parts.text:
A major chord consists of three notes.
The [AUDIO:60:1.0:root note]
the [AUDIO:64:1.0:major third]
and the [AUDIO:67:1.0:perfect fifth]
When we combine all three together we get a [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:major chord]
This creates the bright, happy sound that defines major chords.
Show me the C major scale

The C major scale has seven notes.
Starting with [AUDIO:60:0.5:C]
then [AUDIO:62:0.5:D]
[AUDIO:64:0.5:E]
[AUDIO:65:0.5:F]
[AUDIO:67:0.5:G]
[AUDIO:69:0.5:A]
[AUDIO:71:0.5:B]
and back to [AUDIO:72:0.5:C]
Played together as a [AUDIO:60,62,64,65,67,69,71,72:4.0:scale]

A perfect fifth is one of the most stable intervals in music.
It spans seven semitones.
Here's [AUDIO:60:1.0:C]
And here's G, a [AUDIO:67:1.0:perfect fifth] above
Together they create this [AUDIO:60,67:2.0:strong, hollow sound]
You'll recognize this as the sound of power chords in rock music.
